Van Susteren Teases New Show, Calls On Fans To Follow Her To MSNBC "I hope the Fox audience ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Days before her new show debuts on MSNBC, former Fox News Channel host Greta Van Susteren appeared on her new network to make a plea for her old audience to make the switch along with her. 
Van Susteren, who hosted On The Record for more than a decade while at Fox News, will be the driving force behind MSNBC’s similarly titled For The Record beginning Monday evening. 
She announced her departure from Fox News in a Sept. 6 statement in which she proclaimed the network “has not felt like home” to her for several years. Advertisement - story continues below Greta Van Susteren Announces Career Move: ‘Thrilled To Start My Next Chapter At MSNBC’ 
In an interview with MSNBC’s Rachel Maddow Thursday, Van Susteren said she hopes her former viewers — along with her high-profile guests — follow her to her new television home. 
Maddow, the network’s current ratings leader, asked her guest if fans of her previous show are upset about her move. Advertisement - story continues below 
“I’ve been hit from the right and the left,” she said, “but that happens.” 
In the end, Van Susteren expressed her hope that her new program will attract viewers of all political stripes and network loyalties. 
“I think that the MSNBC audience is going to like me,” she said. “I hope the Fox audience comes over here.” 
As Western Journalism reported this week, several On The Record fans responded to the announcement by insisting they could not follow her to MSNBC. Advertisement - story continues below Oprah Addresses Possibility Of Run For Political Office 
Van Susteren said she also hopes the prominent guests booked on her Fox News program will appear on her new show, vowing to give both Democrats and Republicans “a fair shake.” 
She said she only asks viewers to give the new show a chance, promising a balanced look at the important issues. 
“I like a robust debate,” she said. “People don’t always agree with each other. My own husband doesn’t always agree with me. My own family doesn’t always agree with me.” 
Her primary objective in For The Record , which premieres Monday at 6 p.m. ET, will be to “do a really good job for the viewers and voters at home, because these are very, very serious times.” 
The show will replace rebroadcasts of Bloomberg’s With All Due Respect , which ceased production late last year. 
As Maddow pointed out during the interview, Van Susteren, who rose to prominence during her coverage of the O.J. Simpson murder trial for CNN, will soon become one the few broadcasters to have “had careers at all three of the major competing cable news outlets.” What do you think? Scroll down to comment below.
